questions.text: A patient presents with vaginal discharge, acidic Ph, non itchy yellow discoloration. Lactobacillus count is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
These are the features of normal vaginal discharge under the influence of normal vaginal discharge.

Features of other vaginitis:

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct calorie requirement in a 12 weeks pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Additional calories required in pregnancy:

According to Park

300kcal/day throughout pregnancy.

According to Williams

T1: No additional calories needed.

T2: Additional 340kcal/day

T3: Additional 452kcal/day

But according to the recent guidelines, 300-340 kcal/day in the 2nd and 3rd trimester is what is followed now.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen
questions.solution:
Fig: Types of hymen

In the given image, septation can be seen and hence it is a septate hymen

B. Annular hymen has a small opening

C. Imperforate hymen has no opening

D. Cribriform hymen has small sieve like openings in it.

questions.text: Identify HSG image given below
questions.solution:
Go through the table for better understanding of each and every uterine malformations:

Class: I

Mullerian anomaly:

Mullerian agenesis

Characteristic Features:

Both mullerian ducts absent, only ovaries present

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: II

Mullerian anomaly:

Unicornuate uterus

Characteristic Features:

1 Fallopian tube, 1/2 uterus, 1/2 cervix, 1/2 vagina

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: III

Mullerian anomaly:

Didelphic uterus

Characteristic Features:

2 Fallopian tubes, 2 uterus, 2 cervix, 1 vagina

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: IV

Mullerian anomaly:

Bicornuate uterus

Characteristic Features:

2 fallopian tube, 2 uterus, 1 cervix, 1 vagina, abnormal external contour.

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: V

Mullerian anomaly:

Septate uterus

Characteristic Features:

2 uterine cavities divided by septum, 2 fallopian tubes, 1 cervix, normal external contour

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: VI

Mullerian anomaly:

Arcuate uterus

Characteristic Features:

Everything is normal except the fundus has a dimple in the centre.

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

Class: VII

Mullerian anomaly:

DES(Diethylstillbesterone) related

Characteristic Features:

Hypoplastic uterus, T shaped uterus, cervical collars, Adenocarcinoma cervix and clear cell carcinoma of vagina

HSG findings:

Gross findings:

OPTION a. Unicornuate uterus: A unicornuate uterus has a single uterine horn and is associated with a higher risk of complications such as preterm birth and fetal malpresentation, but it is less commonly linked with recurrent pregnancy loss compared to a septate uterus.

OPTION b. Bicornuate uterus: A bicornuate uterus has two uterine cavities, two fallopian tubes, single cervix and vagina which can increase the risk of miscarriage and preterm birth, but it is less frequently associated with recurrent pregnancy loss than a septate uterus.

OPTION c. Septate uterus: A septate uterus is characterized by a septum dividing the uterine cavity partially or completely. It is the most commonly associated congenital anomaly with recurrent pregnancy loss because the septum can interfere with implantation and increase the risk of miscarriage.

OPTION d. Arcuate uterus: An arcuate uterus has a minor indentation in the uterine fundus but is generally associated with fewer complications and is less commonly linked with recurrent pregnancy loss compared to a septate uterus. It has the best reproductive outcome out of all Mullerian anomalies.

Normal Uterus

Diadelphys Uterus

Septate Uterus

Unicornuate Uterus

Arcuate Uterus

Bicornuate Uterus

questions.text: After 5 days of normal vaginal delivery a woman brought to the casualty at 11pm by her husband with his history of crying, loss of appetite, difficulty in sleeping and feeling of low self esteem. Her general physical examination is unremarkable and there are no worrisome finding from a pelvic examination, which of the following is the best term to describe her symptoms of postpartum?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Postpartum blues.

Other options:

questions.text: Identify the area marked in green
questions.solution:
The midpelvis is the central part of the bony birth canal, located between the plane of the gratest pelvic dimension(above) and the plane of the least pelvic dimension(below). It plays a crucial role during childbirth, as this is the narrowest section that the fetal head must navigate through it.

The key features in the midpelvis are:

  • Level: S2-S3 vertebrae to the midpoint of posterior surface of pubic symphysis
  • AP diameter: 12 cm(extends from S2-S3 vertebrae to posterior surface of pubic symphysis

Option A: Pelvic outlet: It is comprised of Obstetric outlet and anatomical outlet

Option B: Anatomical outlet: Bounded by tip of coccyx(posteriorly), Lower border of pubic symphysis(anteriorly) and ischial tuberosity(laterally).

Diameters: AP: 11.5-13 cm, Transverse/bituberous diameter: 11 cm

Option D: Obstetric outlet: Bounded by the tip of sacrum(posteriorly), lower border of pubic symphysis(anteriorly), and ischial spines(laterally).

Diameters: AP: 11cm, Transverse/interischial diameter: 10 cm

choices.text: Repeat USG after a week and decide

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with previous classical c section is now having breech presentation confirmed on USG at 34 weeks, insists of normal delivery what will you do?
questions.solution:
A previous history of classical caesarean section is an absolute indication for Cesarean section.

Previous classical c-section is absolute indication of c section.

choices.text: Arrange blood and remove placenta via Crede's method

questions.text: The following procedure is done on a 25 year old lady in labor. The cord gets torn. what should be the best thing to do?
questions.solution:
According to Active management of third stage of labour if the cord gets separated during controlled cord traction, do a manual removal of placenta to prevent postpartum hemorrhage. Usually this is done in the OT under general anesthesia.

Manual Removal of placenta

The back of your hand will be against the uterine wall. Feel for an edge of the placenta. Then with your fingers tightly together, sweep your hand back and forth to gently separate the placenta from the uterine wall a little at a time. Proceed slowly until the placenta is completely detached.

Option D: In Crede's method,cord is pulled blindly leading to risk of uterine inversion and hence not indicated.

Option A,B: No need

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with history of 2 weeks amenorrhea came in emergency department with c/o scanty vaginal bleeding. on examination no adnexal mass noted. In lab investigation HCG was 1400mlU/ml, on USG, uterus was bulky, trilaminar endometrium was seen. Patient vitals stable, What is the next step to do?
questions.solution:
This is a case of pregnancy of unknown location.

  • First step to measure HCG levels

Critical titre of HCG at which Gestational sac is visible: TVS:2000 IU/L, TAS: 6500 IU/L

If HCG levels are less than 2000 IU/L, repeating HCG levels after 48 hrs is the most appropriate step.

Next, we need to check if the HCG levels double in 48 hrs or not:

  • If it doubles: Early intrauterine pregnancy
  • If it decreases: Abortion
  • If it increases but doesn't double: Ectopic pregnancy

Pregnancy of unknown origin

questions.text: A 29 year old multiparous female, at 39 weeks gestation is brought in labour. O/E: uterus is term, with 3 contractions every 10 mins each lasting 40-60 seconds, head is 1/5th palpable, fetal heart rate is 140 bpm. On examination, os is fully dilated, sagittal suture in transverse diameter of pelvis for more than 2 hours. Caput++, moulding ++. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
This is a case of arrest of 2nd stage, as she is a multipara and is in second stage of labour(os fully dilated) for more than 2 hours.

Saggital suture in transverse diameter is suggestive of Deep transverse arrest, and alongwith it caput and moulding points towards Cephalopelvic disproportion(CPD).

The fetus is at the level of the ischial spine (which indicates that the fetal head is at the level of the maternal pelvic ischial spines). There is significant molding (++). There is significant caput succedaneum (++) These are suggestive of deep transverse arrest, which is best managed by caesarean section.

CPD is managed by C/S.

Rest all options don't count here.

questions.text: A preeclampsia patient with type 1 Diabetes, post caesarean, on MgSO4, presented with absent bilateral plantar reflex. Lungs clear, RBS -200+, patellar reflex absent. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of MgSO4 toxicity.

Symptoms of magnesium sulfate toxicity are seen with the following maternal serum concentrations: loss of deep tendon reflexes (9.6-12 mg/dL) (> 7 mEq/L), respiratory depression (12-18 mg/dL) (> 10 mEq/L), and cardiac arrest (24-30mg/dL) (> 25mEq/L).

Absent deep tendon reflex(Patellar reflex is the earliest sign of toxicity).

Therapeutic level: 4-7 mEq/l

Calcium gluconate:

The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate 1 g IV over 3 minutes. Repeat doses may be necessary. Calcium chloride can also be used in lieu of calcium gluconate. The suggested dose for calcium chloride for magnesium toxicity is 500 mg of 10% calcium chloride IV given over 5-10 minutes.

Note: Pritchard regimen

choices.text: Bag of water/prolapse of membrane into vagina

questions.text: What is the absolute contra indication of cervical cerclage?
questions.solution:
Contraindications to Cerclage

  • Severe fetal anomaly
  • Intrauterine infection
  • Active bleeding
  • Active labour
  • Preterm ruptured membranes
  • Fetal death

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 32 weeks gestation develop proteinuria and hypertension, doctor suspect a case of placental insufficiency. Which of the following is responsible for placental insufficiency
questions.solution:
Preeclampsia is due to improper invasion of extravillous cytotrophoblast in spiral artery.

Pre-eclampsia is a common disorder that particularly affects first pregnancies. The clinical presentation is highly variable but hypertension and proteinuria are usually seen. These systemic signs arise from soluble factors released from the placenta as a result of a response to stress of syncytiotrophoblast.

This is an image of Multiload 375(a Copper IUCD) and GTN is an absolute contraindication for its insertion.

questions.text: In embryological development, what causes release of testosterone from testis?
questions.solution:
The first stimulus for release of testosterone from fetal testes is HCG from placenta and is development of male internal genitalia.

This Testosterone is converted to Dihydrotestosterone by 5 alpha reductase and is responsible for male external genitalia.

questions.text: What is the ideal advice to a woman who has undergone VVF repair regarding abstinence and postponement of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
She should abstain from sexual intercourse till atleast 3 months post VVF repair and should plan her next pregnancy 1 yr later, after VVF repair.

Timelines of VVF repair:

  • Due to obstructed labor: Repair after 6 weeks(time for infection and inflammation subsides)
  • Due to Surgery:
    • If diagnosed within 24 hrs: repair immediately
    • If diagnosed after 24 hrs: repair after 6 weeks
  • Due to radiotherapy: Repair after 12 mths

Reference: www.uptodate.com

questions.text: Uterine artery doppler done at 22-24 weeks, will help in the diagnosis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Uterine artery doppler is done at 22-24 weeks of pregnancy to predict late onset preeclampsia.

  • Normal finding: Diastolic notch disappears by 22-24 weeks of pregnancy
  • Abnormal finding: Diastolic notch persisting beyond 24 weeks of pregnancy

In high risk pregnancies, it is done in the 1st trimester to predict early onset preeclampsia.

choices.text: Just below the level of umbilicus

questions.text: What is the position of uterus on postpartum day 1?
questions.solution: Immediately after delivery, the uterus contracts (involution) to expel the placenta and reduce its size. Just postpartum, immediately after delivery, the uterus is typically located in the midline of the abdomen, just below the level of the umbilicus-corresponding to 20week. This position is known as the "fundal height". It maintains the same height for 24hrs and then reduces at the rate of 1finger breadth per day. It continues to contract over the next few days and weeks, becomes pelvic organ by weeks and return to its pre-pregnancy size and position by 6 week

questions.text: A primigravida is brought to her home by her relatives just after 1 hour of a vaginal delivery a full-term healthy infant. The baby is doing well. On examination, the patient is hypotensive, hypoxic and has disseminated intravascular coagulation. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is one of the most catastrophic complications of pregnancy in which it is postulated that amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair or other debris enters the maternal pulmonary circulation, causing cardiovascular collapse.

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter the mother's bloodstream, usually during labor, delivery, or immediately postpartum. This triggers a severe and sudden reaction that can lead to life-threatening complications for the mother. Here's an overview:

Causes and Pathophysiology

  • The exact cause of AFE isn't well understood, but it's thought to involve an abnormal immune response to amniotic fluid entering the maternal circulation.
  • This entry can cause an intense inflammatory reaction, triggering widespread clotting (disseminated intravascular coagulation, or DIC), respiratory distress, and cardiovascular collapse.

Signs and Symptoms

Symptoms usually appear suddenly and may include:

  1. Sudden respiratory distress: Shortness of breath, rapid breathing, or difficulty breathing.
  2. Cardiovascular collapse: A sudden drop in blood pressure, leading to shock.
  3. Severe bleeding (DIC): This may manifest as hemorrhaging, with uncontrolled bleeding at various sites.
  4. Seizures and loss of consciousness: Due to lack of oxygen and blood flow to the brain.

Diagnosis

AFE is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on symptoms, as it often presents abruptly during or right after childbirth. There's no specific test for AFE, so doctors rely on ruling out other conditions and recognizing its unique symptom pattern.

Treatment

Immediate, intensive treatment is critical and usually includes:

  • Respiratory support: Often mechanical ventilation to help the mother breathe.
  • Cardiovascular support: Medications and fluids to stabilize blood pressure and support the heart.
  • Blood product transfusions: To manage DIC and severe bleeding.
  • Emergency delivery: If AFE occurs before delivery, an emergency C-section may be performed to protect both mother and baby.

Causes of DIC in pregnancy:

  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Intrauterine death
  • Severe preeclampsia
  • AFLP
  • Abruption

Option A: PPH: No history of excessive bleeding hence ruled out

Option B: Uterine inversion is associated with mismanaged 3rd stage of labour, with the uterus lying outside.

Option C: Peripartum Cardiomyopathy:

  • Starts in last month of pregnancy or within 5 months of delivery
  • Cardiac failure can be seen
  • Not a cause of DIC

questions.text: A primigravida patient presented with soft tender abdomen. On examination fetus is on ROP position. How will you deliver?
questions.solution:
The frequency of posterior presentations(occiput of the fetus towards the sacrum of the mother) in labor is approximately 20% and of this 5% remain posterior until the end of labor. These posterior presentations are associated with higher rates of cesarean section and instrumental delivery

Occiput posterior (OP) position is the most common fetal malposition. It is important because it is associated with labor abnormalities that may lead to adverse maternal and neonatal consequences, particularly operative vaginal or cesarean birth.

If the pelvis is adequate normal vaginal delivery is the preferred mode of delivery
